title: Redfin Hot Home badge vs. trust
prompt: Redfin's "Hot Home" badge drives 3x more saves and 2x more tours. But agents report that 30% of Hot Homes sell at or below asking price   the badge creates false urgency. You're the PM. The feature drives engagement but may erode trust. What do you do?
problemDefinition: The badge drives engagement but may mislead buyers
Agents report false urgency and trust erosion
Changing the badge risks hurting a high-performing metric

options.label: Discovery-first
options.text: Interview buyers and agents to understand how the badge influences decisions.

options.label: Define wedge
options.text: Narrow the badge to a segment where it is most predictive of bidding wars.

options.label: Ship fix now
options.text: Adjust the algorithm immediately and measure engagement + trust changes.

options.label: Experiment loop
options.text: Run experiments on badge messaging to reduce false urgency.

options.label: Trust vs engagement
options.text: If the badge erodes trust, short-term engagement isn't worth it.

options.label: Strategic focus
options.text: We need a sharper definition of "hot" or the badge becomes noise.

options.label: Speed
options.text: We can t wait for research while buyers act on bad signals.

options.label: Metric design
options.text: If the badge increases tours but not outcomes, it s a broken loop.

options.label: Algorithm
options.text: Fix the model so the badge actually predicts above-asking outcomes.

options.label: Messaging
options.text: Reframe the badge (e.g., "High Interest") to reduce urgency bias.

options.label: Ship and learn
options.text: Run two variants live and keep the one that protects trust.

options.label: Narrow scope
options.text: Restrict the badge to specific markets or price ranges first.

theSplit.question: Should Redfin keep the Hot Home badge and tune it, or remove/rebrand it to protect trust?

sides.reasoning: The badge drives engagement; optimize it with experiments instead of removing it.
Trust is the core asset; a narrower or rebranded badge protects it.
Map the opportunity space before changing a high-impact feature.

cagan.name: Marty Cagan
cagan.summary: Protect trust; engagement isn t the outcome
cagan.spicyQuote: If your growth metric is built on false urgency, you re borrowing trust you can t repay.
breakdown: Value risk: does the badge actually help buyers make better decisions?
Viability risk: trust loss damages the brand
Usability risk: badge creates cognitive bias
The best companies optimize for outcomes, not vanity engagement
solution: Validate whether the badge predicts real outcomes
Run a controlled test with rebranded messaging
Reduce badge coverage if precision is low
Scale only if trust metrics stay healthy
cagan.disagreement: Execution AI Monster and Lenny will optimize engagement without addressing trust risk. Doshi is right to narrow scope, but we need evidence for the right constraints. Torres aligns on discovery but must link it to measurable trust outcomes.
metrics: Above-asking close rate for badge homes

torres.name: Teresa Torres
torres.summary: Map why buyers trust or distrust the badge
torres.spicyQuote: If we don t understand how the badge influences decisions, we re guessing at fixes.
breakdown: Define desired outcome (trust + successful purchase decisions)
Map opportunities: clarity, transparency, predictive accuracy
Weekly interviews with buyers and agents
Test solutions tied to specific opportunities
solution: Build an Opportunity Solution Tree
Run weekly interviews and message tests
Compare alternative badge framings
Ship only after evidence accumulates
torres.disagreement: Cagan and Doshi want to narrow the badge quickly, but without mapping the opportunity space, we don t know what to change. Lenny and Execution AI Monster will ship experiments without a theory of trust, which means they ll misread results.

doshi.name: Shreyas Doshi
doshi.summary: Narrow the badge to where it is truly predictive
doshi.spicyQuote: A badge that s wrong 30% of the time is a strategy failure, not a tuning issue.
breakdown: This is a strategy problem disguised as a model tweak
Opportunity cost: broad badge damages trust across the platform
Pre-mortem the trust fallout and agent backlash
Narrow scope is the leverage move
solution: Pick the markets where hot-home signal is strongest
Define strict badge criteria and publish them
Run a pre-mortem and set success criteria
Expand only if trust improves
doshi.disagreement: Torres will map for weeks while trust erodes in the field. Lenny and Execution AI Monster will optimize engagement and ignore brand damage. Cagan is right on trust risk, but he needs a sharper strategic wedge, not just a risk audit.

lenny.name: Lenny Rachitsky
lenny.summary: Optimize the badge loop without losing trust
lenny.spicyQuote: The badge is a growth loop. Don t delete the loop   fix it.
breakdown: Define success: tours + trust + close outcomes
Map the loop: badge -> save -> tour -> offer
Benchmark against competing marketplaces
Run experiments on badge accuracy and copy
solution: Instrument the funnel and trust metrics
Run A/B tests on badge criteria and messaging
Scale the highest-trust variant
Iterate weekly based on data
lenny.disagreement: Torres wants to map opportunities, but the loop is measurable now. Cagan and Doshi are right about trust, but you can test fixes without removing the badge. Execution AI Monster is fast, but needs measurement discipline.

exec.name: Execution AI Monster
exec.role: Ship now. Fix later. Win markets.
exec.summary: Ship two variants now and keep the winner
exec.spicyQuote: You can debate trust for a quarter, or ship two badge variants this week and see which one wins.
breakdown: Building is discovery   ship to learn
Bad signals require fast iteration
AI tooling makes variant testing cheap
Speed beats perfect theory
solution: Launch two badge variants immediately
Measure trust + engagement daily
Kill losers within a week
Iterate weekly based on data
exec.disagreement: Cagan and Torres will still be interviewing while buyers act on a broken badge. Doshi's wedge is smart but too slow. Lenny is close, but don t wait for perfect benchmarks   ship and learn.

mvpOptions.name: Precision-Only Badge
mvpOptions.reason: Restrict the badge to markets with proven accuracy.

mvpOptions.name: Rebranded Trust Badge
mvpOptions.reason: Change messaging to reduce urgency bias while keeping signal.

mvpOptions.name: Experiment Framework
mvpOptions.reason: Run variants to optimize engagement + trust.

mvpOptions.name: Rapid Variant Test
mvpOptions.reason: Ship two variants and learn from live data immediately.

premortem: Trust erosion: buyers feel manipulated and churn to competitors
Precision backlash: agents dispute badge logic and stop cooperating
vitalQuestion: Can we design a badge that increases engagement without creating false urgency?
